_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan  Executive Summary

HF Sinclairs refinery in Sinclair, Wyoming is now known as its Parco Refinery (Parco).  The previously submitted RMP was as Sinclair Wyoming Refining Company, part of Sinclair Oil Corporation. In March 2022, Holly Frontier Corporation acquired all of Sinclair Oils assets.  The corporation became HF Sinclair Corporation, and the refinery in Sinclair, Wyoming was renamed Parco.  The plant, its equipment, and most of its personnel continue operating using evolving work processes and procedures from both corporate entities.  

Our goal is to provide long-term value and sustainability for our stakeholders through diligent pursuit of continuous improvement by investing in our people, equipment, tools and processes.  We will uphold our traditions as an American icon supplying quality products by focusing on Health, Safety, and Environmental excellence.   

We have a commitment to:
	Protecting the health and safety of our employees and neighbors.
	Protecting the environment.  No harm to people.

Accidental Release Prevention

Everyone who works at Parco is responsible for getting Safety & Environmental performance right.  Exceptional Safety & Environmental performance is critical to the success of our business of refining crude oil and delivering quality products.  No activity is so important that it cannot be performed safely and meet environmental standards and requirements.

We work to deliver these goals by:  
	Demonstrating safe and efficient operation of our facilities.
	Pollution prevention; reduction of waste, emissions and discharges; and energy efficiency improvement. 
	Providing a secure working environment by protecting ourselves, our assets and our operations against loss or damage from criminal, hostile or malicious acts.
	Ensuring everyone is informed, well trained, engaged and committed to compliance with legal and other requirements.
	Recognizing those who contribute to improved outstanding safety and envir

onmental performance.
	Producing quality products for our customers.
	Communicating effectively with our employees, neighbors, customers, public interest groups, and those who work with us.

All employees and contractors work together to accomplish these goals, and when necessary, utilize Stop Work Authority to intervene before an unsafe condition or environmental violation may occur. 

Description of Parco and the Regulated Substances Handled

The refinery was constructed in 1923 and operated by the Producers and Refiners Company (PARCO).  Sinclair Refining Company purchased the refinery in 1934 and operated it until 1972, including a period of operations as a subsidiary of Atlantic Richfield Company.  In 1972, PASCO purchased the refinery, then in 1976 it was acquired by Sinclair Oil Corporation and operated as Sinclair Wyoming Refining Company.  In March 2022, Holly Frontier Corporation acquired all of Sinclair Oils assets.  The corporation became HF Sinclair Corporation, and the refinery in Sinclair, Wyoming was renamed Parco.  

Description of Refinery Processes:
Parco includes modern process units typically used for production of petroleum fuels, atmospheric and vacuum distillation, hydrotreating, reforming, fluidized catalytic cracking, delayed coking, alkylation and associated supporting operations such as crude oil unloading, sulfur recovery, blending and crude oil/product storage and transport.  The NAICS code for Parco is 32411. 

Parco manufactures the following:

Asphalt
Jet Fuel
Propane
Diesel
Fuel Oil
Sulfur
Gasoline
Petroleum Coke
Liquefied Petroleum Gases
Renewable Diesel

RMP Program - Definition of Process and Regulated Substance: 
The RMP rule defines a process as Any activity involving a regulated substance, including any use, storage, manufacturing, handling or on-site movement of such substances, or combination of these activities.  For the purposes of this definition, any group of vessels that are interconnected, or separate vessels that

are located such that a regulated substance could be involved in a potential release, shall be considered a single process.  The RMP rule defines regulated substance as any substance listed pursuant to section 112(r)(3) of the Clean Air Act as amended, in § 68.130. (Re: 40 CFR 68.3).  

Per the RMP definition, PARCO has the following RMP regulated flammable substances in its processes:

Pentane
n-Butane
Isobutane
Propane
Ethane
Methane
Isopentane
Hydrogen
Flammable Mixtures

PARCO has the following regulated toxic substances in its processes:

Hydrogen Sulfide (H2S)
Sulfur Dioxide (SO2)
Ammonia (NH3) 

Of the above flammable and toxic substances, only n-Butane, Propane, and Isobutane exceed the RMP threshold quantity for flammables.  There are multiple processes where flammable mixtures present in quantities above RMP threshold.  None of the toxic substances listed above exceed the threshold quantity for toxics.  Based upon threshold quantities and process definition, Parco has the following nine RMP-covered processes: 

	Sweet Crude Unit (582 Crude Unit)
	Sour Crude Unit (581-583 Crude Unit)
	Reformer Complex: Reformer #1HDS, #2HS, #3HDS, LEF, Naphtha Splitter, and #1 ARU, #1 & #2 SWS, #1, &#2 SRU   
	FCC (Fluidized Catalytic Cracking Unit, sometimes referred to as 780)
	Alky Complex which consists of GRU, SRGU, Alky, Poly, Spheres and Bullets
	Tank Farm: Only of those with RMP applicable Flammable mixtures, Tank 528 
	HC-RDU: Hydrocracker, Renewable Diesel, #1 and #2 Hydrogen Units
	#4HDS (Diesel Hydrotreater)
	Coker Complex: Coker, #3 & #4 ARU, #3 & #4 SRU, #3 & #4 SWS, Flare Gas Recovery, CAF

Other processes at the Parco either do not have regulated flammable substances or contain such substances in quantities below the RMP applicability threshold.

Multiple processes contain H2S and SO2.  This is a byproduct from removal of the naturally occurring sulfur in Crude Oil.  It is converted in our SWSs, ARUs, and SRUs to elemental sulfur.  The maximum qu

antity of H2S and SO2 in any process does not exceed 10,000 pounds and 5,000 pounds, respectively.  

Ammonia is used in several processes in amounts less than 10,000 pounds at each process, mainly for air pollution control.  Projects are underway to replace this with urea or aqueous ammonia. 

Because the quantities of these toxic substances are less than their respective RMP threshold values, none of the toxic substances are RMP reportable.  Nevertheless, our prevention and safety programs include these toxic substances.   

Accidental Release Prevention Program and Process-Specific Prevention Steps

Parcos accidental release prevention program includes the provisions of the Risk Management Plan (RMP) program and OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) Program summarized below.  We work proactively to provide a safe workplace for each employee and promote safety practices among employees for their health and welfare.  This is accomplished by actively assuring wide employee participation in a thorough PSM program and appropriate safety training.  

The PSM program is managed by at the site with a local team, with accountability to the Refinery Manager, with technical input from corporate resources.   

Our management recognizes and firmly believes in the need for a safe environment for both the refinery and the local community.  Policies ensure that our efforts of prevention through planning, training, process controls, timely maintenance and communication with our neighbors will help prevent unforeseeable releases of regulated substances.  Should a release nevertheless occur, our trained personnel, in conjunction with trained personnel from the community, will respond, mitigate and contain the release. 

PSM & RMP Program:
For the RMP-covered processes, we use OSHA's PSM standard and EPAs RMP rule as the basis for our accident prevention program. 

Employee Participation:
We encourage employees to participate in every aspect of process safety management and accid

ent prevention.  Specific ways that employees participate are documented in the Employee Participation Plan and in procedures for each program element.   

Employees have access to all information that is part of the accident prevention program.  Information is located in the operations areas and available in electronic documentation systems.

Process Safety Information:
We keep technical and safety documentation for each unit that falls under the PSM standard and RMP rule in electronic systems available to all employees.  These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis, and process safety critical information.  

Various workgroups are assigned responsibilities to keep the process safety information updated.  A table summarizing the reference documents and their location is available.  Copies of critical information are found in the Main Control room.

Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in Safety Data Sheets (SDSs).  This information is supplemented by documents that specifically address known corrosion concerns and any known hazards associated with the inadvertent mixing of chemicals.  For specific process areas, we have documented safety-related limits for specific parameters (e.g. temperature, pressure, level, flow) for monitoring and control of operations.  Parco ensures that the process is maintained within these parameters using process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained personnel, and protective instrument systems.

We also maintain numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of the equipment.  This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, etc.  

Process Hazard Analysis:
We have a comprehensive hazard review analy

sis program to ensure that hazards with processes are identified and controlled to acceptable risk levels.  

We use hazard and operability (HAZOP) analysis as the primary methodology to perform these evaluations, supplemented with a checklist on Human Factors and Facility Siting.  High hazard scenarios identified in the HAZOP are then analyzed using LOPA (Layers of Protection Analysis).  We use teams of knowledgeable, trained personnel from safety, maintenance, operations, environmental, engineering and plant management.  The team evaluates potential process hazards and identifies accident prevention and mitigation measures.  The team makes recommendations about systems, procedures or practices to put in place to ensure that risks are mitigated to tolerable levels. 

The PHA team findings are shared with management for review and resolution.  Implementation of systems, procedures and practices is based on a determination of risk associated with the findings.  Changes to equipment may require a scheduled unit shutdown (turnaround) and capital funding.  All approved mitigation options being implemented in response to PHA team findings are tracked until they are complete.  The PSM group manages all information about the PHA report, recommendations and resolutions. 

The PSM group maintains the PHA schedule to ensure the studies are completed on the required 5-year schedule.  A Corporate PHA specialist performs Quality Control on PHA studies.  Corporate also issues standard guidance to ensure consistency of hazards and their controls throughout the HF Sinclair network.  

Operating Procedures:
We maintain written operating procedures that provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities involved in each covered process.  

Additional information within the operating procedures and manuals includes a process description, a process chemistry, an equipment description, operator responsibilities, safety concerns, chemicals in the unit, utility systems and contro

l systems. 

Procedures are used in the Training Programs.  Procedures are written by Complex Trainers using a standardized template.  Procedures are part of the continuous improvement efforts, as trainers and correct any issues as seen in their training efforts using the sites management of change (MOC) system.   

These procedures are used to train personnel in their responsibilities at the unit, to reference during operation of the unit and to provide checklists necessary for unit operation.  These procedures are periodically reviewed and certified as current and accurate.  These procedures are maintained current and accurate by revising them as necessary to reflect changes made through the MOC process.  

Training:
We compliment the written operating procedures with a comprehensive training program.  New employees receive initial training in refinery operations and safety practices.  After successfully completing this training, the new operator or technician receives a manual that guides them to an understanding of their responsibilities.  Training manuals include descriptions of the equipment, how it works and what is involved in its operation.  Drawings and graphics help the new operator picture the vessels and equipment in the unit.  

New operators are paired with experienced operators to learn process-specific duties and tasks.  All new operators are tested on what they have learned, in oral, written and demonstration testing.  When operators demonstrate adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they are allowed to work independently. 

All operators periodically receive refresher training to ensure that their skills and knowledge are at a proper level.  The refresher training is conducted at least every three years and is documented for each operator.  All critical operating procedures are drilled on at least every three years.    

Parco trains personnel in safety, health, security, and emergency response, includin

g applicable OSHA standards.  

Contractor Safety:
Parco ensures that contractors are trained in the specific hazards they may encounter when working at our site.  Contractors are chosen and vetted based on their safety records, training, and qualifications.  Contract employees are not allowed onto the refinery property until they have received approval and training.  

Pre-Startup Safety Review:
We conduct a Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) for any new equipment, facility or modification that requires a change in the process safety information.  It is closely aligned with our MOC process.  This review provides an additional check to ensure construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready.  

The PSSR review team uses checklists to verify all aspects of readiness.  A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves as quality assurance by requiring verification that the accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.  The completed and signed PSSR checklist is included in the PSM files. 

Mechanical Integrity:
We have well-established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels and storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems and devices, controls, pumps, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition.  The basic aspects of this program include:

	Conducting training of maintenance personnel
	Developing written procedures 
	Performing inspections and tests
	Correcting identified deficiencies
	Applying quality assurance measures

These activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment.  We use current versions of applicable API, ASME and company standards as the basis.

Maintenance personnel receive training on an overview of the process, safety and health hazards, applicable maintenance procedures, emergency response plans and applicable safe work practices to ensure that they can perform

their job in a safe manner.  Written procedures for testing and inspecting help ensure that the work is performed consistently and provides a basis for training.  Maintenance personnel receive refresher training and through certifications required for inspection and testing.  Personnel are required to take the necessary certification training and tests on the appropriate schedule to keep current.  

Personnel perform inspections and tests to ensure that equipment functions as intended and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits.  If a deficiency is identified, the deficiency will be corrected before placing the equipment back into service, or if needed the Refinery Leadership will review the use of the equipment and determine what actions are necessary to ensure the safe operation of the equipment.  

The refinery's inspection and testing personnel (employees and contractors) are certified to proper standards and have current training certificates on file.  Personnel are certified to API 510, 653 and 570 specifications.

Hot Work and Safe Work Practices:
We have long-standing safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety.  Examples include:

	Control of Hot Work 
	Control of the entry/exit of all personnel on refinery property and process areas
	A lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance
	A procedure for safe removal of hazardous materials before process piping or equipment undergoing maintenance in opened
	A permit and procedures to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space.

These procedures and other measures, along with training of all affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that our operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.

Management of Change:
We have a comprehensive system to manage changes to processes.  This system requires that any change to items such as process equipment, chemicals, tech

nology (including process-operating conditions), procedures and facilities that affect a covered process are properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.  Changes are reviewed to ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and to verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change.

Operating and maintenance personnel are trained on the change, as applicable to their job responsibilities. 

Parco tracks all MOCs through an electronic system overseen by the PSM workgroup.  

Incident Investigation:
Parco has an established incident investigation program.  As part of this program, Parco investigates all incidents that resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in, a major uncontrolled emission, fire, or explosion, involving one or more highly hazardous chemicals or regulated substances, that presented serious danger to employees in the workplace or imminent and substantial endangerment to public health and the environment.  The goal of each investigation is to determine the root cause and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident.

The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent recurrence and shares with refinery management for resolution.  Corrective actions taken in response to the investigations team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding or recommendations is documented and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the findings.

We retain incident investigation reports for at least five (5) years so that incidents can be reviewed during PHAs.  

Compliance Audits:
To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, we periodically conduct audits to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the RMP Rule and PSM Standard are adequate and being followed.

This is done at least every three years using a team of independent auditors with help from refinery staff.  The audit team reviews documentation and records, inspects the site and interviews personnel to determine compliance.  The audit team then develops findings for refinery management resolution.  The final resolution of each finding is tracked, documented and the two most recent audits are retained onsite as part of the PSM file. 

Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:
Our processes have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation.  The accident prevention program summarized above is applied to our program Level 3 RMP-covered processes.  The prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors. 

In addition to the accident prevention program, we have safety features to help contain/control releases, detect releases and reduce the consequences of a release.  The following types of safety features are used in various process units:  
	Hydrocarbon detectors with alarms 
	H2S and SO2 detectors with alarms
	Pressure relief valves that discharge to flare systems.  The flare captures and incinerates episodic releases and is monitored by video cameras.
	Emergency Isolation Valves 
	Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g. high or low temperature, levels, pressures, etc.)
	Alarms and interlocks for specific process parameters 
	Redundant instrumentation and equipment (spare and back-up systems)
	Release mitigation
	Deluge systems for over pumps, compressors and other equipment
	Trained emergency response personnel (both refinery personnel and local emergency response personnel)
	Personal protective equipment (e.g. fire-resistant clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus, bunker gear, eyewash systems, safety showers, etc.)
	Wearable H2S and SO2 detectors for all in process areas.  (Gas badges)
	Uninterruptable Power Supply systems

for process controls and safety critical instrumentation.

If a release does occur, these release prevention systems help PARCO contain and control the release in a way that minimizes risk to personnel and the public.

5-Year Accident History 

Parco has had no RMP-reportable incidents that occurred during the previous 5-year period.  

The incident investigations noted in the Prevention Program submittal were releases below RMP limits, or of a non-RMP chemical.  We have had no employee or contractor OSHA-reportable injuries due to Process Safety issues in the reporting period.   


Emergency Response Program

We maintain a written emergency response program to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released.  The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including:

	Proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures
	Evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation
	Notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs
	Cleanup and decontamination requirements 

In addition, we have procedures that address maintenance, inspection and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment. 

Employees receive, as part of their initial and ongoing refinery training, instructions and procedures for carrying out their specific duties. 

The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to refinery processes, changes in legal requirements, or refinery policy.  The emergency response program changes are administered through the MOC process, which includes informing and/or training affected personnel in the changes.  The overall emergency response program for Parco is coordinated with the Local Emergency Planni

ng Committee (LEPC).  LEPC members include local emergency response officials, local government officials and industry representatives.  Parco has periodic meetings with the LEPC and has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations, including the fire department.  This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.

In addition to the periodic meetings, we conduct periodic emergency drills that involve the LEPC and emergency response organizations.  These include Field Exercises and Table Top drills.    

To provide annual refresher training to local emergency responders regarding the layout of the facility and the hazards of regulated substances in the refinery and to ensure that local emergency responders get to meet and interact with Parcos personnel in addressing response actions.

Our programs and training help to ensure that we meet the requirements of the emergency response program and have a practical and effective plan in place that has the full confidence of the LEPC and local emergency response groups.
